Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 was always one of my less favourite of the Harry Potter films and I was slightly alienated from it in comparison to the other Harry Potter films because when I first watched it I found it a little bit too dark for my tastes, and I was thrown off by the fact that it no longer had the actual school of Hogwarts in its story.

In the many years since the first time I watched it, I myself have grown as a person, and watching all the Harry Potter films together leading up to this one allowed me to really harness the feeling of things to come. Although I still consider Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 to be one of my less favourite films of the series, I enjoyed it significantly more this time.
The flaws in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 are largely on the basis of the fact that it is the first of two films split from a single novel. While I am glad that the filmmakers did this to allow more Harry Potter cinema to live on, this leaves Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 with a constant feeling of it being more of a prequel than a film of its own right. There isn't too much that happens in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 that isn't small story elements dramatised and stretched out, and it is always leading up to something which happens in its sequel. It still has a lot of interesting elements, but it is inferior to its successor. Admittedly, I also missed the presence of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizadry and many of the characters I had grown to love from watching them grow up and teach there. But I accepted that that was just part of the story and I had to make due.
Also, the pacing is a little rough. At first, the film begins with a quick representation of the preparation for facing the dark world head on and getting people to safety. Things jump off in a rush and the pacing is constantly moving between quick and slow over the course of its 146 minute running time, and in that the film tends to lose track of certain elements. Within a very brief period of time, Harry Potter's treasured pet owl Hedwig is killed as Rubeus Hagrid attempts to get Harry Potter to safety. The story doesn't value Hedwig enough to give his death much dramatisation, and in a second he is forgotten. I don't know if this is the case with the novel, but in the film they just don't value a character like Hedwig enough to dramatise his death. He may be just an animal, but it's clear he meant something to Harry Potter, and the fact that he isn't valued enough as a character to receive a proper farewell just left me upset. When Buckbeak was thought to have been killed, he received dramatic treatment, and the fact that Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 couldn't do the same for Hedwig upset me. It seems as if it upset Harry Potter less as well. I'm sure that if Daniel Radcliffe was given the right moment on screen he would depict his emotional response to the situation well, but since the script didn't give him that moment it isn't dealt with properly.
But despite an inconsistent pace, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 still serves as strong entertainment.
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 manages to hit a new point of climactic darkness for the series. Exiting from its Hogwarts setting, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 creates a thrilling atmosphere for the way that the characters have to be constantly on the move to prevent the enemies from catching up with them. The adventure theme that was absent in the preceding two Harry Potter films is present in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1, and it makes it vastly entertaining. The scale of the adventure is huge and it is very dark and thrilling, so it returns to the roots of its original entertainment while maintaining the superior dark theme which has grown as the film series has developed. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 combines some of the best themes from the preceding Harry Potter films and ends up as another entertaining entry into the series.
And visually, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 is effective as well. Despite exiting the beloved Hogwarts setting, it manages to go into a bunch of settings which create both agoraphobic and claustrophobic moods. The visual style of the film is intense and enhances the dark atmosphere of things, especially through use of its cinematography which always captures the setting in the intended mood. It constantly captures the scale of things excellently, be it the large scale of the intro sequence, the small intense scale of its intense character-driven scenes or the simple focus of the actors' faces when they deliver intense lines. Essentially, the cinematography in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 is its best since Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, and it is a more notable visual quality of the film than its powerful visual effects and grand production design which all worked to keep the scale of the spectacle up and strong over the course of the film. The musical score keeps the film strongly intense as well.
Yet with the dark adventure theme of the film and the large scale, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 never steps far away from the importance of its characters. Director David Yates hits a high point for his role as the director of Harry Potter films because he finds the balance between keeping the film as a character focused story and a large thrilling adventure, and he deserves praise for stepping up his game in preparation for this film. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 is the finest of David Yates' entries into the Harry Potter film series, and he gives the script a lot of treatment which ensures that it is entertaining and allows the actors plenty to work with. Without problem, the cast of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 give it their all and make the experience thrilling and compelling.
Daniel Radcliffe who has spent 10 years dedicated to the role of the titular Harry Potter, and as he has grown from being a young boy, so has his character. The entire process of things has been exhilarating over the course of all preceding six Harry Potter films, and Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 is the most intense and mature role yet. Harry Potter steps into a world where every turn could be potential death. With him and his two closest companions on the run from everything, it's like the entire world is his Precinct 13, and he can never give up on fighting back to make the world a better place for the good hearted. Daniel Radcliffe proves to easily capture the mindset of his character being in a world of evil, and it makes the entire experience more realistic and believable. With a rough edge and intense ability to put himself in the appropriate emotional state of thinking, Daniel Radcliffe spearheads his iconic role with ease once again, and he makes an excellent lead for the story.
Rupert Grint manages to do the same thing as Daniel Radcliffe with a performance that is equally as impressive. Rupert Grint shows off the most mature elements of Ron Weasley to date, temporarily eliminating the humourously awkward demeanour so that audiences can see the negative effect that the changing world has had on him as well. There is one specific scene in the movie where he delivers the darkest character elements of the entire series, and it is so different from the usual Ron Weasley character that it is rather shocking. This reveals the endeavour of Rupert Grint's skills as an actor, and it uncovers a side not previously explored which intensifies and complicated the experience of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1, all while revealing just how skilled an actor Rupert Grint has become. His performance in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 is his finest of the series so far, and it is impressively dramatic.
Emma Watson also manages to step up to the same plate and tackle to complicated elements of Hermione Granger with ease. In a world where booksmarts aren't as effective as in the school setting, she serves as an example of the flaws in the school system. Yet through her courage and wisdom, she manages to grow into a hero of her own for the story who makes it stronger and shares an impeccable chemistry with Daniel Radcliffe and Rupert Grint. As one of the three actors who have to hold the screen for most of the time in the film, more than in the preceding films, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 serves as a strong testament to her ability to hold the screen.
There are few actors who get all that much screen time outside of these three due to the focus resting solely on them, but the supporting cast manages to pull of some strong efforts as well.
Helena Bonham Carter comes back into the dark role of Bellatrix Lestrange once again in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1, and she manages to dominate dark atmosphere with the insanity she puts into the role, making yet another powerful impression on the series in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1. Her evil demeanour and dark way of interactive with the cast is impressive, and it boasts some of her finest talents as a character actress. She faces the role head on without fear, and allows the fear to sink into the hearts of the viewers that encounter her instead and the resulting effect is thoroughly thrilling and entertaining.
Robbie Coltrane's return to the role of Rubeus Hagrid is one of his most dramatic yet. Although facing minimal screentime, he has some serious moments with Daniel Radcliffe which allows their characters to share the relationship they have with audiences so that they can look back at where it all started. Robbie Coltrane delivers another effective, albeit brief performance as Rubeus Hagrid, and considering that he is my favourite character of the entire franchise I was rather pleased with the strength of his time on screen.
And Imelda Staunton's return to the screen in the role of Dolores Umbridge takes no time before it reminds viewers just how much the character is truly hated. She is brought back as an antagonist again and plays on her corruption with power, and the simple presence of her angered me due to how I hated the character more than any other as well as pleasing me because of how skilled Imelda Staunton is at the role. Her presence is awesome and makes Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 a greater viewing pleasure.
Lastly, Ralph Fiennes manages to come back to the role of Lord Voldemort once again for another powerful antagonistic performance. While the effect isn't as strong this time around because it's been seen before and is to be expected, but the fact that he naturally takes on the dark and evil elements of the character makes him an effective villain again.

So while Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 features a few pacing jumps and feels a bit much like the prequel that it is, it is more intense than any of the preceding Harry Potter films and returns to its adventure territory with dark themes which makes it an improvement over its two predecessors.
By magic means, this movie split-up managed to be successful. It was the most uneventful entry in the series for sure, but worth watching.

Harry, Ron and Hermione are on the run, taking refuge in dark forests and by the sides of rivers surrounded by an invisible barrier to prevent capture, and whilst there's tension and threat in the air the wait for anything interesting to happen is quite long. It's like going on a countryside walk, just when you think you are back at the car and can finally rest you find out there's more to go, and it can be exhausting, that's how The Deathly Hallows when the three argue, read and sleep on their escape. Thankfully the bits intercut between are intriguing, emotional and sometimes thrilling, such as the fast paced forest attack, the discovery of the all important sword and Harry's birthplace in the sleepy snowy town. The opening sequence is good fun too, where Hagrid and co disguise themselves as Harry and get caught up in a fantastically over the top chase through the bustling streets of London. You'd think Harry Potter would look stunning in 3D but sadly the overwhelming darkness destroys any dimensionality and depth, leaving a rather flat experience, although some moments featuring snakes and wands have a decent 3D pop.

The tone in the Hallows part one is certainly darker that's for sure. There's also very little joy for Potter and co as they hit the road in search of the remaining Horcuxes; and a means with which to destroy them. What's a Horcrux you say? Well, a Horcrux is an item that Voldemort has used to store away a piece of his soul. By doing so, he makes himself almost unbeatable because to kill him completely, you also need to find all the Horcruxes and destroy them too. Sneaky bloke is old Voldemort. The nearest muggle (us normal humans) comparison would be losing your wallet, car keys and cell phone - really - could you survive without them?

Hallow's part one is beautifully made, and visually stunning. It's also the most mature Potter film to date, and the stakes in the story have never been deadlier.

A crazy, crazy mix between The Return of the King and Picnic at Hanging Rock, the latest instalment in the Harry Potter world, is my personal favourite so far.

After being ready to cry my eyes out less than 3 minutes in, I calmed myself down a bit and got ready to take the movie in. I've seen The Deathly Hallows Part 1 before, in Civic Dendy Premium cinema to be precise, but only that once, so I bought it on DVD and watched it again so I'd have everything fresh in my mind for this review.

Hallows manages to be completely epic, and have intense action/chase sequences, without ever succumbing the mindlessness that is accepted of adventure/action movies of late. It's the darkest Harry Potter movie to date (yes, even more so than The Half Blood Prince, which was the only Harry Potter film I've enjoyed on the big screen since the original), and this works hugely in its favour. I mean, okay yes there's a certain element of "Kids Movie" that's been completely lost, but let's be honest, why the fuck does that bother me? Most children in the world would be able to handle this sort of thing perfectly fine if they were allowed to, it's just the fact they're not allowed to that creates this sort of taboo, and because they're supposed to be scared by it, they are. I remember being young and having my dad read this book to me, he said he liked the book, and so I automatically had in my head that it was gonna be the most terrifying thing ever, because he was an adult, and children aren't allowed adult things... Grumble grumble... Anyway. Ahem, sorry. Back on track.

So yeah, it's dark, and as far as I'm concerned that's a good thing. What else is good? Well the special effects sure are bloody special, I'll tell you that much! Anybody who reads my reviews often (do those people exist?) will know that I have a whinge about effects-driven movies. Well, Hallows goes all out with the CGI, sure thing, but it doesn't adversely effect the film in the slightest. It improves it, it allows us to make real the things that are not, in order to propel the rest of the experience. It's technological magic woven into a great film, it doesn't try to be the entire film itself (see Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix for a great example of this, the script relies entirely on SFX, rather than the merits of the story, what the fuck? What kind of script writer says "Then there's a giant fire dragon, then there's some glass, and then BOOM and then, uh, they can make up some dialogue later. Seriously, the direction was great, but nobody had the power to save that piece of crap).

The animation sequence they used for the Deathly Hallows story was also really cool. Somewhat reminiscent of the intro to Hellboy II: The Golden Army. If any of you've seen that you'll get what I mean. Anyway. I thought it was pretty spectacular, and would've been cheaper than trying to do it the live-action way. See! Budget can't compare to brilliance.

Most of all I was impressed by characters and actors. Yes, yes, I know I often am, but hey, what you gonna do? I liked this Scabior guy particularly (above). I didn't recognise him when I first watched The Deathly Hallows but he's actually Nick Moran (from Lock, Stock & Two Smoking Barrels, The Bill and The Amazing Grace). I'll be keeping an eye on him in future.

Other spectacular entries to the cast included Bill Nighy (Doctor Who, The Boat that Rocked, the Underworld trilogy,Valkyrie, Pirates of the Caribbean 2 and 3, Hot Fuzz, Shaun of the Dead, Portrait of Evil, Wild Target, Love Actually) as the Minister of Magic; Rufus Scrimgeour (Bill Nighy's another personal favourite), as well as Rhys Ifans (The Boat that Rocked, Elizabeth: The Golden Age, Hannibal Rising, Little Nicky, Notting  Hill) as Xenophillius Lovegood (I've adored Rhys Ifans since primary school when I first watched him play Adrian in Little Nicky with Brett Price), Jamie Campbell Bower (Camelot, The Prisoner, Winter in Wartime, RocknRolla, Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street) as a young Gellert Grindlewald (who was supposedly the other Dark Lord, way before Voldemort's time) and David O'Hara (Cowboys & Aliens, The Tudors, Wanted, Doomsday, Braveheart) as Albert Runcorn (come on! He had a role in Doomsday! Like I'm not gone love him).

There was a couple of things I thought were less than fantastic though. The whole entire scene with Bathilda Bagshot made zero sense. I had the advantage of having read the books, so I got what was going on, but anyone who hasn't, wouldn't. Not to mention the fact that the subtle Nazi undertones of the book give way to a Final Solution regime, complete with propaganda in ye olde Third Reich font. And uniforms. With red bands. Yes. Seriously. I mean, I love Nazi films, but aren't we getting sick of when something goes wrong, we decide that everyone's Hitler? I dunno, it all seems a bit tired to me.

But know what? The fact that they have Nick Mother Fucking Cave alone is enough to make this a solid effort, and then when you chuck in the fact that it's actually a good movie! I got tired of The Philosophers Stone quickly, and The Chamber of Secrets even more so. The Prisoner of Azkaban I honestly still kind of enjoy. The Goblet of Fire was woeful, and The Order of the Phoenix took everything bad about it and made it worse. Half Blood Prince was quite good, but only as a lead up to this, which honestly is just a lead up to Part 2. Which I await anxiously.

It is not one of the best Harry Potter film, but the movie still entertains you and leaves you wanting more.

Combined, the two parts of "The Deathly Hallows" are about 4 and 1/2 hours long.  Now, some might say that it is overkill.  But I say it's great because it allows the novel to be thoroughly adapted.  The fact of the matter is, there really was no way of making this adaption shorter.  Unlike all of the other Potter books, there are so many tiny details that are crucial to the plot, that they can't be left out.  So yes, I support the decision to make "The Deathly Hallows" a 5-hour adaption.

As for "Part 1" specifically, this is the plot-driven part.  This is the one that has a lot of the character development and establishes a lot of the stuff that pays off in "Part 2".  That's not to say this movie doesn't have any action.  This is still another fun Potter film.  The big aerial chase at the beginning and the scene at the Ministry of Magic are both some of the best action scenes in the series.

I will be honest though.  This movie does slow down during the second act.  Harry and Hermione have an awkward dancing scene, but that's it.  The film does pick back up once Harry and Hermione visit Godric's Hollow, so hang in there.

"The Deathly Hallows Part 1" is a very close adaption of the book, and I was happy about that.  Should you see it?  Yes, absolutely!  This is "Part 1" of the finale that so many have long-anticipated.  But I should warn you.  One of the best things about Rowling's writing is that every little detail comes into play in this finale.  So before you watch "The Deathly Hallows" (both parts), at least watch all of the movies again.  Really, you should read all of the books, but at the very least, rewatch the movies.  That way you can see all of those little details pay off.

Deathly Hallows 1 is a bit uneventful, but sets the stage for the final chapter really well. Harry Potter is all grown up in this much darker film in which he and his friends Ron and Hermione must hunt horcruxes (pieces of Voldemort's soul) to destroy them and finish the Dark Lord once and for all. The magic of Hogwarts is missing from this movie, leaving a much needed filler for that enchantment of the Wizarding World. Unfortunately we don't get that, but this movie is still very good. There are some really intense scenes (the forest chase, the climax) and the last ten minutes are very emotional and touching. The acting once again is top notch, the main protagonists completely owning their roles. The action is suspenseful and exciting, and there are some great character moments within the film. The score is eerie, capturing the essence of the film. There are some pacing issues, and the movie doesn't cover much ground in terms of plot (being part 1 of 2 and all) but it still doesn't disappoint, and makes fans and audiences alike eager for the final chapter. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 gets 4/5 stars (A-).

	The movie I'm doing is Harry Potter: The Deathly Hallows Part 1. It is about this wizard boy named Harry and he travels to different places to find stuff to defeat an evil wizard guy. The things they need to find are horcruxes. A horcrux is a part of the soul that you can hide to make you almost impossible to defeat, but if someone finds the horcrux and destroys it then the person becomes weaker. They are trying to defeat Tom Riddle a.k.a. Lord Voldemort because he wants to take over the wizard world. 
	The movie starts out at a Harry's friend Ron's  house. The headmaster of a wizard school known as Hogwarts died and he was Harry's friend. This old person comes and gives Harry, Ron, and Hermione something Dumbledore left them. Then later there is a wedding and it gets caught on fire by some deatheaters some of Voldemort's followers. Harry and his friends' apparate (teleport) to London and go to a café. There are more deatheaters there and there is a small battle. Then they go to a house that other people used for the Order of The Phoenix which was an order that tried to stop Voldemort 2 years ago. Then an elf/servant named Kreacher tells them that his master had a horcrux but then he gave it to him before he died but then someone named Mundungus Fletcher stole it. So then the elf/servant goes to try and find him. He comes back with Mundungus and a free elf/servant named Dobby. Mundungus tells them that he sold to a lady. That lady is a very important person in the Ministry of Magic. Harry and his friends kidnap people who work there and use a potion to make them look like the people that they kidnapped. They get the horcrux which is a necklace right when the potion starts to where off. They apparate to a forest where one of his friends get hurt. Harry helps his friend and then his other friend sets up a tent that looks really small but on the inside it is really huge. After she sets that up she sets up a protective border around their camp. The spell wears off and then wizard-hunters capture them and take them to Harry's enemy from school's house where they have a prison in their basement along with some of Harry's other friends. Splitting Deathly Hallows into two films is a good idea considering how it's the most story heavy of the seven Harry Potter books yet Part 1 still comes across as an unfinished mess even when taking that into account. All the previous Harry Potter films felt at least a little self-contained as films by themselves with this having the burden of being the first part to one story. The film rarely lets up though and keeps the action focused and thrilling and a lot of thought was put in the characters and their relationships. The action being shifted from outside Hogwarts also makes this film feel fresher than before. It's a bit of a disappointment as a film by itself and feels very unfinished but when viewed alongside its companion film, it's more compelling.

DISCLAIMER: OK, so I am a little behind in my reviews, so I will try to keep this as brief as possible, but I am a huge Harry Potter fan, so it's unlikely.

This is the second time I watch this movie, and I am leaving it with a very different feeling from the first viewing. Initially, I felt the movie was very well made but a little slow. Although it's true in the book the first half is not as action-packed as the second, I thought the movie was a good 3.5 / 5.

Now, after 2 years, it's a whole other movie. It's damn right amazing. Soooo much action, so much excitement the whole way through. Yes, there was that 20 minutes of relatively little action, but that is to be expected. It was relatively very loyal to the book and yet felt even faster paced.

There are some amazing scenes in the second darkest film in the series (the darkest of all being Deathly Hallows part 2). The diner exchange is fantastic. The Nagini attack is scary as $#^@. The scenery throughout is mind boggling! Cinematography epic win! Some of the best footage of scenery in a mainstream film.

The acting bar is again raised, this time to a solid performance from all actors. Although if I need to be honest, among the leading three I feel Daniel Radcliffe is the weakest while Emma Watson is the strongest. I understand it must have been tough selecting these actors at the age of 11 trying to see who would blossom into the strongest actor a decade later.

Music is stellar. VFX are photo-real and amazing. Production value is through the roof (as it should be considering the budget!). Overall, Warner Bro's have done a fantastic job bringing the books to life! Particular kudos to Yates on a fantastic series of movies. Really came out of nowhere for the Win!

Overall, an excellent and necessary watch before the finale: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2!

Harry, Ron and Hermione must grow up fast, as they leave Hogwarts behind to take on the powerful Lord Voldemort. This time there is no help from teachers or mentors. Even though the movie is long at 146 minutes, it really just feels like things were getting started.  I hate the decision to cut the movie in two halves. It allows for more detailed story telling but it becomes less disciplined and becomes a little overburdening. There is a barrage of minor characters both new characters and barely mentioned characters from early in the series. It is a little hard to keep everything straight, even for an enthusiastic nerd, like myself. Thankfully knowing every minor character and every detail is not essential to enjoying the experience. It is nice to see that there is more to plot to unfold and evolution of characters to keep things interesting this far into the series. One thing is for sure you will want to watch Part II soon after this, so reserve a big block of time.

The acting is finally under control once again (but Rupert Grint still seems a bit at a loss as to whether or not to act sentimental or make a silly face) but still...it just stopped feeling like Harry Potter.  Maybe that's just the fact that it's essentially a tree movie, being filmed three fourths in a forest, whereas we've been too used to Hogwarts. Still it sets itself up very well with one of only two sad moments in the franchise (Dobby's death), and finally Voldemort in triumph with the Elder Wand...as disappointing as this addition to the series was in a sense, I was pretty damn excited to see how well Part 2 would be.

After viewing Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, I declared it the worst of the Potter films so far. It was quickly replaced, however, by Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince. Still, when all was said and done, I enjoyed the films, as they still managed to mostly display what had made the more entertaining predecessors so enjoyable. Unfortunately, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (an extraordinarily tedious name to say or type), is the new weakest entry for the series, and it could hardly be considered enjoyable.

Harry, Ron, and Hermione set out on a quest to destroy the Horocruxes which keep Voldemort immortal. And that's essentially the entire plot.

There are a number of things that make the Harry Potter films enjoyable. The characters are the main reason, but also visual effects, music, humor, and the magical setting of Hogwarts. Unfortunately, very little of this is contained in this penultimate chapter.

Absolutely none of this film takes place in Hogwarts, which means that almost none of the characters that we've come to very much enjoy seeing are in this film. Harry, Ron, and Hermione eat up almost all of the screen time, while their character flaws are more noticeable than ever. Other than Bellatrix, most of the villains get only a single scene.

Neville is seen once, gets one line, and has completely lost his shy, clumsy personality that made him so likable in the previous films. Luna Lovegood is hardly in the film at all. And of course, almost none of the Hogwarts teachers are in this film. The one character that DOES return however, is Dobby- the house elf that makes Jar Jar Binks seem intellectual. Still, he only gets a few scenes. New characters like Xenophilius Lovegood and Rufus Scrimgeour get sadly little screen time.

There is almost no humor in this movie. This is most likely due to the darker tone, but the film is so dreadfully dull, a little more comedy would've helped things considerably.

The visual effects don't get too many chances to show off in this film compared to the previous entries, but the effects do sparkle when they're on screen. Admittedly, there is one less-than-convincing snake, but other than that, the visuals are great, though less so than the last four films.

The pacing is so absurdly slow that one will feel every second of the 146 minute run time. While the other Potter films have also boasted lengths of similar size, they never felt nearly as long. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows drags and drags.

I didn't even feel like it was building up to anything either. Other than in the very last scene, there's no great sense of anticipation. The whole film feels plotless and aimless. 

There were really only two truly well done scenes. One involved Hermione Granger reading a sort of fable about three men meeting death, which utilizes some really nifty animation, though this sequence would've probably been enhanced by some music, as there is none during this segment. The other brief, but notable scene involves Bellatrix torturing a main character. This is notable because it's painful and horrific, without actually showing anything. It's by the strength of the onscreen acting that this scene is so successful.

Thankfully, the acting has not slipped much. The main trio of Radcliffe, Grint, and Watson are still solid in their roles. Still, as they're basically the only characters we see for most of the film, there's not much else to say in regards to acting.

The music was immensely disappointing given the composer on board: Alexandre Desplat. There was not a single moment where the score stood out. The entirety of the music felt like underscore, though in all honesty, that's really all it was. Now, this isn't really Desplat's fault. There simply isn't much for a score to do in this film, as nothing really ever happens during the movie. Still, this seems to be the weakest of the Potter scores thus far (a spot previously held by the score for the Half-Blood Prince by Nicholas Hooper).

Boring, uninteresting, and painfully slow, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 takes nearly everything that made the previous films so entertaining, and throws it all out the window. A disappointment in nearly every respect, Deathly Hallows: Part 1 lacks the sense of magic, wonder, and -most importantly- fun that this film very much needed. Deathly Hallows: Part 2 already has the expectations of keeping up the standard of a successful film series. Now it has to make me feel like watching this tedious and frightfully dull film was actually worth it.

"I should be the one to kill Harry Potter."

And here we go with the beginning of the end of the Harry Potter films. It had a rough beginning (Sorcerer's Stone), but the fact that the franchise has improved since its beginning is beyond me. Now we come to the second to last film, and it's incredible, even if we know that the film ends in an abrupt cliffhanger.

Voldemort (Ralph Fiennes) has gone at his most powerful and leads an all-out mission to destroy Harry Potter (Daniel Radcliffe). He and his followers have taken over the Ministry of Magic and even Hogwarts itself. Harry, along with Ron (Rupert Grint) and Hermione (Emma Watson), bond together to find the remaining Horcruxes that can destroy Voldemort once and for all. But since Dumbledore (Michael Gambon) never told Harry where to start, the quest turns into a nightmare, filled with romantic tensions, fears of heavy death and abductions, and dark secrets that might end Harry's journey for good.

Returning to the franchise in this second to final chapter includes Helena Bonham Carter as Bellatrix Lestrange, Tom Felton as Draco Malfoy, Jason Issacs as Lucius Malfoy, Alan Rickman as Snape, Timothy Spall as Wormtail, John Hurt as wandmaker Ollivander, Robbie Coltrane as Hagrid, Brendon Gleeson as Mad-Eye Moody, Bonnie Wright as Ginny Weasley, Julie Walters and Mark Williams as the Weasley parents, David Thewlis as Lupin, Evanna Lynch as Luna Lovegood, Matthew Lewis as Neville Longbottom,  and Imelda Staunton as Delores Umbridge, Harry's worst enemy from the classrooms.

New to the film includes Bill Nighy as the Minister of Magic before Voldemort takes control, Domihnall Gleeson as Bill Weasley, Ron's older brother, and Rhys Ifans as Xneophilius Lovegood, Luna's loony dad.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 is incredible. Simply incredible. This is the darkest Potter film released at this point. Don't be fooled by the PG-13. Actually I think this almost got an R rating due to a dream sequence where Harry and Hermione are making out nude. But of coarse, the film has an audience, and the film gained its PG-13 and made the nude scene carefully where the film's not R. And either way, that nude scene is kind of creepy, dream scene or not.

The emotional intensity has heated up its highest here. Some of my favorite moments include a dancing scene between Harry and Hermione, Ron's fears of being left out, and in the most disturbing scene, Bellatrix in a very wild and creepy torture sequence to one of the three, and even though the true torture is not fully shown, that scene still leaves an impact due to the looks on the others who hear the torture. 

The cinematography shines, probably the best cinematography in the entire franchise, even outdoing the outstanding shots in Half-Blood Prince. The dark looks are outstanding, the locations are dazzling, and even if those stones were CG, I couldn't tell, cause I was still wowed by the cinematography.

There's also some amazing visual effects here, obvious cause the Harry Potter franchise is known for its outstanding visuals. Dobby and Kreatcher return, and look outstanding as ever, the trio use heavy makeup in a very memorable Ministry infiltration scene, which is one of my favorite scenes in the film, Voldemort's creepy snake appears in some disturbing moments, and the best effect, a scene where there's not one, not two, but seven Harry's in one room. ("Wow. We're identical.") That still blows my mind. I'm also wowed by an animation storybook sequence explaining the films title.  

The casting, once again, is brilliant. We know how excellent Radcliffe, Grint, and Watson are in their roles, and how mature they've got in the years we've known them, so I'll cut it short. As usual, they're excellent as ever, particularly Watson, who shines best. Grint is still very funny, and Radcliffe is still good in the emotions. Ralph Fiennes is perfect as Voldemort, and makes a villain that leaves tons of impact. The other big actors here are mostly given cameos (Carter, Rickman, Issacs, Coltrane, etc.), cause this is Harry, Ron, and Hermione's picture, but still, the small roles these actors have amazing presence and dominate the picture, especially Helena Bonham Cater and Alan Rickman.

For the final two films, the film is scored by Alaxendre Desplat, and it's spectacular. In some moments, you'd think that John Williams returned, but in others, you don't. But that's fine, cause Desplat's score is the best score that Williams never made. It's exciting, it's chilling, especially in the opening theme, and in some cases, really haunting. I'm impressed, especially that it's not Williams.

David Yates had brilliant direction in Order of the Phoenix, but disappointed me a bit in Half-Blood Prince. Here, Yates is back on track, and Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1 is the most trilling, dark, disturbing, chilling, exciting, and emotionally satisfying Potter film, until Part 2 came out, which really sums up both films and the franchise as a whole.

This is due to the filmmakers decision to split the 7th book in the series, "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows" into two films. I have never read the Harry Potter series, so I am unaware of how much was cut in the adaptation process. With that said, this is surely one of the weakest efforts in the whole Harry Potter series. Harry and Voldemort are preparing to fight each other, in this film. There are some minor skirmishes between Harry's wizard gang and Voldemort's death eater gang, but otherwise, the focus is on Harry, Ron, and Hermione trying to identify, find, and destroy an object that holds part of Voldemort's life. The three actors who play the main characters have never been more emotionally invested, but I would have liked more of the other folks. Given Malfoy's role in the last film, I expected him to have more than two scenes in a two-and-a-half-hour film. That's not a problem, if you enjoy spending the majority of time with our three musketeers. Ron grows more possessive over Hermione, while Harry and Hermione try to cope with the isolation of their mission. If the director had cut some scenes, I would have taken in the isolation more so than the boredom they must have endured in their several months alone. The opening is beautifully shot though, depicting what all of the characters must do before leaving for the first battle. Hermione's moment is especially heartbreaking, both in the opening and how it affects her character later in the movie.

The special effects are as good as they have always been, but there were some scenes that suffer from too-much-CGI. I fully understand why any scene with a magical-looking spell, mystical creature, or broomstick-flying has CGI, but then there is the unusual motorcycle/broomstick chase scene in the first half hour. For practicality and safety, I also understand why the scene had so much CGI, but the action was not as thrilling as it could have been, had they tried to recreate the magic of the moment without magic. And I did not care for the prolonged deathly hallows tale, told through silhouetted, Burton-esque animation. I won't take everything else for granted though, because this is a Harry Potter film and, as a part of such a grand story, it is a fantastic predecessor to what should be a spectacular finale. (I have never seen Pt. 2, by the way.) Pt. 1 does not stand well on its own, due to lack of significant events or changes, but in the context of the series, it should definitely satisfy fans.

O penúltimo capítulo da série Harry Potter, "Relíquias da Morte - Parte 1", é uma escalada perfeita de suspense, magia, aventura e principalmente drama, se configurando como um dos melhores filmes da saga já feitos. Exercendo desta vez uma crítica aos grandes e macabros sistemas políticos e militares que ocorreram na metade do século vinte na Europa (como, por exemplo, o nazismo), o filme obtém um sucesso genuíno ao parodiar estes sistemas, adaptando-os à trama da série com muito sucesso e muita competência. A linguagem visual do filme é simplesmente espetacular: o diretor David Yates investe em uma fotografia muito escura e muito sombria, dando ao filme um aspecto sinistro e dramático (muito semelhante a fotografia de filmes que retratam a Segunda Guerra Mundial, por exemplo). O roteiro de Steve Kloves e a direção de Yates trabalham com quase a mesma perfeição realizada pelo livro de mesmo nome da J.K. Rowling, sendo um dos filmes mais bem adaptados de toda a série. Algumas sequências se assemelham tanto as do livro que até mesmo os diálogos e as ações dos personagens são incrivelmente parecidas. Os atores estão ótimos, com destaque para o trio principal, que evoluiu muito neste penúltimo filme. Emma Watson consegue mostrar do que ela é capaz neste capítulo do que em qualquer outro anterior. Rupert se sai muitíssimo bem na sequência da briga entre ele e Harry. E Daniel é, sem dúvidas, o maior destaque dos três (pelo o menos neste capítulo), interpretando muito bem as cenas de drama e de ação. Ralph Fiennes (Lord Voldemort) está deslumbrante em uma das primeiras cenas do filme, metendo medo com a sua voz rouca e maligna. Jason Isaacs também se destaca em seu papel como o Lucius Malfoy, transmitindo o medo e a aflição do seu personagem com maestria. Os efeitos especiais, apesar de discretos em algumas cenas ( as cenas da cabana, do Ministério) e nada discretos em outras (a cena dos Sete Potters e a batalha aérea) são incríveis. A confecção de Dobby é espetacular: e aliais é este personagem que vai trazer uma das cenas mais comoventes e belas de toda a série. Este é um filme belíssimo, sonhado por todos os fãs e feito somente para quem sempre terá o Menino-Que-Sobreviveu guardado em seu coração.

It's finally here: the first part of the official end of the Harry Potter series. The books have long since passed, but fans that need their Harry Potter fix still have two movies left with which to indulge themselves. And the fans seem to know it if box office numbers have anything to say on the matter. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (part one) pulled in $125 million in the U.S. on its first weekend alone, and over $200 million extra internationally, smashing the franchise record of $102 million domestically for Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire. That number is nothing to scoff at either, especially considering the controversy over the splitting of the final book into two films. Fans of the books often wondered how they were going to pull off The Deathly Hallows back when we all thought there was only going to be one movie; the book, after all, is 784 pages long, and as much as the filmmakers have cut from previous books, doing so for The Deathly Hallows is incredibly tricky considering the number of plotlines needed to fulfill the agenda set up in The Half-blood Prince.

For that reason alone, The Deathly Hallows (part one) is perhaps the closest an HP film has come to the original source material since the original two films (directed by Chris Columbus). Couple with the two movie split, this is a huge gamble. If you're going to split a movie in half, you have to justify that by creating a complete narrative that avoids leaving the audience with a cliffhanger, but is also open enough to warrant seeing the final installment. The Deathly Hallows (part one) comes close to meeting this task, though knowing whether the film is truly effective depends on what happens in the final half of the sequence. Still, what The Deathly Hallows (part one) offers
fans is an action-packed fantasy film that doesn't forget its core audience and sets the stage for the true climax of the series in part two.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (part one) drops the audience right where The Half-Blood Prince left them: in darkness. Voldemort has risen to power, influencing and threatening the safety of the wizarding world. The Ministry of Magic is rapidly trying to control public hysteria, mudbloods (wizards born of muggle parents) are being targeted and killed by Voldemort's army, and Harry Potter is in greater danger than he ever was before. But Harry Potter and his friends have a job to do: they have to find the last few horcruxes-the pieces of Voldemort's soul that prevent the Dark Lord from completely dying-and destroy them so as to end Voldemort's reign and bring things back to the way they were. And in their journey they'll discover more about themselves, the world around them, and what they must do and sacrifice to protect everything they hold dear.

The Deathly Hallows is perhaps one of the darkest of the Harry Potter films, even when compared to The Order of the Phoenix. Unlike previous films, the government-level adjustments to wizarding society in The Deathly Hallows are manipulated directly by Voldemort, instead of by the fear of what people are often unwilling to acknowledge (in the case of the wizards in The Order of the Phoenix, it is the fear of Voldemort's return, which, of course, proves to be a somewhat ironic fear, since it more or less plays into Voldemort's hands). The result is a more personal kind of darkness: characters betray one another-even people you'd never expect-proving that it has become increasingly more difficult in this world to know who to trust; likewise, people quickly begin to sacrifice their freedoms in the fear of something they feel helpless to resolve. Astute viewers will immediately begin to draw parallels between The Deathly Hallows and our own world, particularly given the changes in the last few months in the U.S. and elsewhere. Unlike our world, however, the one presented in The Deathly Hallows is reasonably projected from Voldemort's rapid removal of wizarding society's security blankets. Hogwarts is no longer the safe haven it had always been, even given the handful of dangerous incidences that have occurred there over the franchise. For Harry and his companions, this is doubly problematic, because what The Half-blood Prince showed them is that Voldemort can get to them no matter where they go. The Deathly Hallows continues this trend to even greater effect-without security blankets, Harry, Hermione, and Ron are both on the run and more desperate than ever to find the horcruxes they need to destroy Voldemort for good, because sooner or later, Voldemort and his men will find them and kill them.

The shift in tone, beginning most clearly with The Order of the Phoenix and culminating in The Deathly Hallows, coupled with the radical change of scenery, also make possible the ramping up of the action that has been teasing us for six movies. There are fewer restrictions on the characters, good and evil--both because of the conditions of the emerging world and the original source material--and this freedom is reflected clearly in the action. Duels are rugged and uncontrolled-an obvious contrast to the previous six films, all of which take place in the confines of school and the educational structure. Likewise, The Deathly Hallows is unfettered by a narrative dominated by children, not simply because the main characters are now practically adults; if anyone remembers the enormous duel between Dumbledore and Voldemort-and loved it as much as I did-then they'll be equally pleased with The Deathly Hallows, where advanced levels of magic are in higher frequency and presented in situations entirely external from the school, thus adding a certain degree of realism to the story. That is to say that magic in The Deathly Hallows is not centered on training in a school, but on using it to achieve one's personal goals, whether that be murder, manipulation, or pleasure. For example, we see the polyjuice potion used both as a deception for protection against certain death and as a spy device under much more serious circumstances than spying on one's fellow classmates-specifically, to kill. I've always been pleased with how the filmmakers have attempted to render the magic from the books, and there are certainly no complaints here.

What The Deathly Hallows seems apt to do is open the floodgates that were gently cracked in The Order of the Phoenix (in the Dumbledore/Voldemort duel), but pushed closed again by The Half-blood Prince (arguably one of the worst films of the series). Harry, Hermione, and Ron are all obviously coming into their own, more secure in their abilities and unafraid to show it. Likewise, the loosening of Voldemort's leash-the danger posed to him by the Ministry of Magic and its allies--makes the first major sequence a thousand times more threatening than anything we've seen before precisely because of where it is placed: the muggle world, with a handful of overlapping spaces. The Deathly Hallows is far more action-oriented than previous franchise films, which makes for a far more rushed plot than HP fans might be used to. While this might seem like a criticism of the film, the quick pace actually enhances the desperation exhibited by the characters. Harry, Hermione, and Ron all ride on the same sheer dumb luck (as McGonagall would say) that got them through every major film plot in the series, not because they have a choice-which one might argue they had when they were younger-but because there are no other options.

That doesn't mean the plot doesn't have its problems. For viewers of the films who are unfamiliar with the books, much of what happens in The Deathly Hallows will feel incomplete. This is because the first half is intimately tied with the second. There are a number of elements that ring suspiciously of deus ex machina, for example, but which will-we can hope-be resolved nicely in the second part. Whether this is a problem of advertising or simply a mistake on the part of the filmmakers is difficult to say. The one crucial failing of the producers for The Deathly Hallows is that they have decided to wait until next summer to release the final installment while also doing very little to help viewers understand why both pieces have to be seen to get the full picture-I would argue that non-readers of the series are not particularly interested in issues of adaptation, which is fair.

One of the other flaws with the film is the visuals. While most of the CG renderings are beautifully done-such as the first major fight sequence and the various uses of magic throughout the film-the one weakness involves much more complicated CG elements: characters. One of my biggest pet peeves is in how filmmakers use CG. While the Harry Potter films have never been at the highest end of the visual scale, the rendering of several familiar characters in The Deathly Hallows could have been done more efficiently, particularly since I know what will happen in the second installment. Dobby, for example, looks less detailed than he did when he first appeared in The Chamber of Secrets; the same can be said for Nagini-Voldemort's snake companion, who has a fairly prominent role in this particular film. Maybe this has more to do with my familiarity with the graphics quality of the last few years than with any degradation of the visuals in Harry Potter, but as much as I enjoyed the film, I couldn't help taking notice of how certain visuals didn't seem up to par. The good thing to take away from this criticism, however, is that the film is not as poorly rendered as The Expendables (2010), which did such a piss-poor job of rendering CG blood that I literally laughed out loud the first time the dark substance appeared on screen. To put it another way: the worst of the graphics in The Deathly Hallows are simply average, rather than exceptional (which I think the final installment of the film deserves).

But the shimmering star of the film has nothing to do with good graphics, high-flying action, or an appropriately rushed plot. Perhaps the greatest part of The Deathly Hallows is the chemistry between the main actors--Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson, and Rupert Grint--and the supporting cast--who are only briefly on screen. Radcliffe, Watson, and Grint work superbly together. Their comedic and emotional timing is arguably the strongest it has ever been, demonstrating that we are dealing with a group of actors who have not only grown into themselves, but into the characters as well. In a way, they have grown with their characters and seem remarkably at ease fulfilling their roles. Humor is particularly well played throughout the film, both for the main actors and the supporting cast members. Ron, as always, acts as comic relief, but his jokes are no longer placed in moments of childish fancy, since doing so would cheapen the moment. Instead, Ron's humor always acts as tension relief either during less-stressful sequences or at the ends of particularly dark ones. The supporting cast members are equally as funny. Fred and George (James and Oliver Phelps), for example, share a particularly touching moment early in the film in which humor is used as a kind of comforting device-and it works, giving the impression that these characters and the people surrounding them are all part of a real family unit. As much as the story focuses on Harry, Hermione, and Ron, the secondary cast members are equally as important, representing the solid ground on which the main characters rest their hopes and dreams. The fact that the secondary characters-with the exception of one or two new faces-move as smoothly on screen as our heroes-both in how they display the kaleidoscope of emotions that the opening thirty minutes of The Deathly Hallows offers and in how they relay humor to themselves and to us-makes losing oneself in the film remarkably easy. That's what we go to the movies for, isn't it? To lose ourselves. To become part of the world being presented before us. 

In the case of Harry Potter, we're losing ourselves in a kind of dream, one that is full of adventure and wonder in a way that our own mundane world seems to be incapable of providing (it isn't actually incapable, but so many people assume it is). That's what we've been riding on since 2001: the awe-inspiring beauty of a world whose magic changes the very nature of how people interact with their surroundings. The Deathly Hallows is a continuation, but also a culmination and expansion on those moments of immersion. Now all we have to do is wait until July to lose ourselves one last time.

I haven't always been kind to the film adaptations of the Harry Potter books because they always seemed to be missing something. J.K. Rowling created a world on the page that was robust and alive, populated by dozens of interesting characters and wondrous things to behold. The movies, mainly after the second installment seemed to miss the point. They always felt like Cliff Notes summaries. That's a complaint I've had with this series for about the last four installments. Yet, here we are at the end and at last they've gotten it absolutely right. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part I is the beginning of the end, the top half of a two-part finale that concludes in July. This is the best installment of the series, in my opinion, and the truest to Rowling's vision. Harry's destiny has been looming all along through some admittedly tiresome fore-bearings and now those portents of doom finally come to a head.

This film finds Harry being hunted by the evil Voldemort and his Death Eaters who know that the moment the lad turns 18, his protection spell will be lifted and he will be fair game. Some of Harry's professor's attempt to help him escape when an ambush is sprung that sends Harry, Ron and Hermione on the lam. The trio's flight from Voldemort, and the now-corrupt Ministry of Magic, makes up the bulk of the movie as they try and obtain the horcruxes, objects that contain various pieces of the dark lord's blackened soul.

They set off across the English countryside never fully aware of who they can trust. The scenes outdoors (there are no scenes at Hogwarts) leave time for a surprising amount of character development especially in the now strained relationship between Harry and Ron. Outwardly, Ron is worried that Harry is endangering in his family - inside, he fears that Harry is winning Hermione's heart. What comes of that conflict is something that has been missing from his series all along: these three young actors that we've watched grow up since childhood - Daniel Radcliff, Rupert Grint and Emma Watson - are finally given room to act. Their performances are compelling. They are angry, frustrated, tired, hungry and scared out of their wits. They play each note just right. Grint plays Ron with an undercurrent of bitterness. Watson began her performance as a bookworm but has now become the logic center. Radcliff maintains his performance with a perfect heir of dread and melancholy.

Those performances are the foreground of a movie that is beautifully produced. Director David Yates and his cinematographer Eduardo Serra (who shot Blood Diamond and Unbreakable) match the story's grim tone by keeping the skies eternally overcast and the landscape fore-bidding and lonely at the same time. This film, unlike previous installments, has a heavy tone that owes more to The Lord of the Rings. This time they aren't content with just a press stamp copy of the books. They really make the story come alive especially in moments when we think the trio is safe but then the trap is sprung. There are visual tricks here that I didn't expect, most delight is a breathtaking, and oddly beautiful, animated sequence told in shadow as Hermione reads the story of The Deathly Hallows.

There is a sense of melancholy that sets in with Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part I and not all of it has to do with Harry's fate. In a way, we sense the closing of an era. These are characters that we have come to love, that we've watched grow up and now they head into their final battle and their destiny. We know that Part II will focus mainly on tying up loose ends (I hope it will be more than that) but if the bottom half of this finale is as compelling as the top, we're in for a very wonderful send-off.

Harry Potter movie has developed unbelievably. Not only is he more confident (no longer the kid with the glasses and the awkward smile), you really feel that he could be the champion of the story, and yet you still see how much pain and anguish he goes through. You feel his follies, you get the sense that he is utterly lost without Dumbledore. You see his anger that has culminated for the past six movies, and you see him breaking down. By Al Alexander
The Patriot Ledger

       There are a lot of wands, magic and otherwise, in "Harry Potter and the Deadly Hallows." Plain ones, short ones, ornate ones, and yes, big ones, but they all go limp as the wildly popular franchise nears its climax. 
      Yes, if ever a movie needed a healthy dose of Viagra, it's this one. Easily the worst of the seven films that have trickled out since 2001, "Deadly Hallows" forgets everything that made the Potter films so endearing.  And that would be the depth of felling it holds for its wide array of charmingly eccentric characters.
        In "Deadly Hallows," that magic dissipates behind a thick cloud of melancholy and the type of angst befitting an apocalypse more than a sprightly fantasy. It's a bummer, all right, but not as big a bummer as the realization that this time around we'll be without Hogwarts, and the cliques, rivalries and romances brewing within its formidable walls. 
        That means no Manerva McGonagall, Horace Slughorn or Moaning Myrtle, and only fleeting moments with Hagrid, Snape and a posthumous Dumbledore. Heck, even Ralph Feinnes' dreaded Voldemort barely puts in an appearance. The rest of the time, we're stuck with the three least compelling of J.K Rowling's creations: Harry, Hermione and Ron. 
      OK, they were cute as kids, but now they're adults, quite dull ones, too. And as such, they've reached an age when Hollywood demands that they go on a coming-of-age road trip, complete with romantic entanglements, naked embraces and huge misunderstandings. 
      The film would like you to believe it's Voldemort and his ruthless band of Death Eaters at the heart of our heroes' woes. In reality, it's Steve Kloves' cumbersome adaptation of Rowling's final Potter novel that's the bigger threat. 
       Long (141 minutes), unfocused and utterly confusing to anyone who hasn't read the books, Kloves script tires to cram as much of the novel in as he can. Well, everything but the heart and charm. Sure there are the occasional transcendent moments, like the naked embrace Harry and Hermione share in Ron's vivid imagination, and the moment when Harry visits the graves of his murdered parents. But most of the film consists of static shots of Harry, Hermione and Ron exchanging expository dialogue.
          Yet, despite all the explanations, you're still baffled by what in the heck is going on. If you figure it out, let me know. But I think it has something to do with Harry and his wizardly sidekicks trying to round up pieces of jewelry and other trinkets containing concentrated amounts of Voldemort's wicked evilness. 
        It's just a lot of smoke - literally and figuratively - that evaporates into thin air without meaning or context. Far more interesting, but much less explored, is the darkness lurking deep inside Harry, Hermione and Ron. It's some pretty unsettling stuff, too. But you believe it's the script bringing it the surface more than Voldemort. 
        At least it doesn't seem as phony as the sub-par special effects, used mostly in service of the film's three or four lame action scenes. The only memorable visual trick arrives when it becomes necessary for six of the kid wizard's closest allies to drink a potion that transforms them into Harry clones. 
        Alas, seven Potters are not better than one, but at least the bit of cinematic trickery distracts you from the laborious script and David Yates' prosaic direction. It's Yates' third Potter film (he also did the previous two and will handle the grand finale coming out in July) and he's still searching for consistency in tone.
         The movie is literally all over the map, with Yates struggling to find an effective way to mix the various strands of romance, comedy, drama and adventure into a cohesive unit. Often, "The Deadly Hallows" feels like bits of four different movies poorly cobbled together. 
           The best parts, as you might expect, come via the Death Eaters and their boss, Valdemort. They are frightening, but also quite funny, mostly courtesy of Helena Bonham Carter's marvelous portrayal of Drago Malfoy's crazy aunt Bellatrix Lestrange. More of her cyclonic bursts of energy would have made "Deadly Hallows" much less of a drag, as it fumbles and stumbles its way toward next summer's finale. Until then, let's pray to the pagan gods that next time the wands won't be so wan.

I walked out dumb-founded and amazed.  I know a lot of peeps are gonna dog it for being incredibly long and boring.  And they're going to complain about the cliffhanger ending, and that part one should have been trimmed down, but what can I say?  I loved the incredibly faithful adaptation of the whole movie.  I'm sick of Hogwarts and Quidditch, those plotlines are lame.  This was something new, something epic.  I was incredibly happy to walk out staking claim that this first part of the two part finale is my favorite Potter film yet.

I'll even go ahead and say it; I loved the dancing scene.  Dance levity in any movie tickles me in all the right places.  If you thought the ice skating scene in King Kong was sappy and unnecessary then prepare to suck a fuck when you come complaining to me about this scene.

Harry Potter And The Deathly Hallows- Part 1 is now the fifth most underrated movie of the HP franchise list. I don't see why this sequel has got less reviews as well as Harry Potter 4 and 5. Remember, this is the setup to our big climax that came out a year later. The story is that now Harry has the instructions to kill Voldemort with a bit of help from Professor Slughorn from the last movie, the trio have now discovered that Voldemort's powers are hidden in seven different objects known as Horcruxes. They already have destroyed the Philosopher's Stone in Harry Potter 1 and the diary in Harry Potter 2, now five more remain. If the trio don't destroy these Horcruxes, then Voldemort will remain immortal. Even if this book was split into two movies, it is still the first half of Harry Potter 7- Part 2 and counts as the other half of that film. SO there's no need to give separate percentages each. Even though it's the first half of the last movie, the franchise has already taken the ballsy direction. You thought killing Dumbledore was insane, well killing Dobby who was a fun character and was always trying to protect Harry in Harry Potter 2 is just as insane as that. I think this is the moment where we start to lose our beloved and important characters and this has been happening since Harry Potter 4 and Harry Potter 5. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 gets a 10/10.

Some may say this is just the prelude to the final half-chapter of the series so not much lends itself to action or involvement for the fans, however, I'll have to completely disagree.  This movie was full of great wizardry, special effects, emotion and compelling storytelling.  And to think we still haven't seen Hermione and Ron kiss yet!  Harry is bolder and the film continues to dip into darkness as Voldermort is clearly winning the early stages.  It'll be interesting to see who sides with who in the end.  It is also to see as the series has gained notoriety, bigger and better actors continue to get cast in some of these side roles, which greatly influence the storyline.  There are still some instances that don't make much sense like Harry skinny dipping in a frozen pond and surviving without hypothermia or Harry's inability to recognize Ron is under the influence of the amulet even though Hermione is right there saying he is before Harry kicks Ron out of the group briefly...All in all...a solid installment that definitely sets up the second half of the Deathly Hallows to be a sweet finish.

The problem with this Harry Potter film, and the previous two for that matter, is the lack of utilization from their talented supporting cast. The three main characters take up 90% of the screen time and, quite frankly, Ron and Hermione drag the film down with weak performances. Harry might be decent but he can't carry 2 hours and 10 minutes of a 2 hour 30 minute film single-handedly, especially with two iron anchors(his two costars) chained to each of his ankles, and it really isn't fair to expect that of him.

Dark, thrilling, and exhilarating than ever in this incredible entry
for the beginning of the end in the Harry Potter series. I went to the
midnight showing of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows pt.1 and was
exceptionally amazed.As I'm sure you know the story; Harry, Ron, and
Hermoine have left school to destroy the objects called Horcruxes,
which are needed to defeat the dark lord Voldemort while he rises to
power. The tagline 'nowhere is safe" really does set the dark and
engaging tone of the movie because the trio is constantly being hunted
and attacked by death eaters and snatchers. With Voldemort now in
control of the wizarding world hes sees that anyone who isn't
pure-blood (One parent wizard/witch and muggle) are abominations to
society. The director made that whole scenario feel like a World War 2
anti league which made to enemies cause to be important towards
everyone in the wizarding world. And Then also there was a scene when
the tale of three brothers was told in a animated Tim Burton like theme
which was interesting non the less. Though detail was taken out from a
few important key points but hey, its a movie based off a book they
don't always get everything, right? I also have to add that the chase i
the beginning to get Harry to safety was making me shake in
anticipation, one of my favorite scenes no doubt. But one thing that
did bug me was the big story gap between the wedding and the breaking into the ministry which felt went by rather fast.With so much intense action throughout the movie also needs proper music. Alexandre Desplet did the soundtrack for pt.1 and did an awesome job in creating a dark and exciting mood to each scene. Every actor gave it their all in
making themselves really feel the characters and never before was it
this good.Emma Watsons torture scene put my teeth on edge, and Harry's emotions from the troubles that surround him made him a grade A Harry Potter from the book. Dan, Rupert, and Emma will go down in history for this magical and extravagant series, but never have the risks and dangers ever been on such high a scale which is why this installment feels better than all the others combined. As a Harry Potter fan since the beginning I can honestly say I was pleased with every minute and that this not only was the greatest, dark, emotional, intense, and
action packed Potter film it defiantly will be one of the best movies
of the year. But this will please any hardcore fan as it will supply
you with everything you would need for the inevitable Deathly Hallows
pt.2 and with the epic follow-up of pt.1 the series will prove that
these books and movies that were part of so many others childhoods will always deliver big so then they can later on in life teach down that
Harry Potter was one of the greatest series of all time.                                      -Brandon A. Oberdorf

It doesn't have anywhere near as much action-packed sequences as it's predecessors but luckily doesn't need them. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is an intriguing ride and builds up towards it's much anticipated other half. It finally focuses on Harry's ultimate goal of escaping and defeating "he who must not be named." While it mainly centers on developing plot and paving the road towards it's final counterpart, Deathly Hallows is an engaging film promising an action-packed, climactic follow up.
